review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1689172340}
review:
VERLIES II is an unusual specimen, and while it might look a lot like some cool classic CRPG like Might & Magic or Eye of the Beholder, it most certainly isn't.  There's RPG aspects, but the bulk of the game is really a browser/Flash like arcade experience where you click the screen to move around (which is just a matter of changing the wallpaper image), and use the convoluted control schemes once you change the wallpaper background to a dungeon theme.  There's "combat", which is a laughably bad matter of watching a static image slide left and right, clicking occasionally to attack or block when the sprite slides to the right spot... it's painfully badly done.  

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The artwork here is terrible, it's a hodge-podge of amateurish "My First Wacom Tablet" style drawings used instead professional looking game assets.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget to arrange someone who can create graphical assets properly, or lack of talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low, enough on its own to deter gamers.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

For gameplay purposes, because the user interface for this game is mostly just 2D static images... it might as well be a browser game.  And we all know, Steam isn't here to compete with Chrome and Firefox.  If the game can be done in a web browser, it's just not rich or compelling enough to appeal to serious gamers on PC.

Some of the defects in the game can be attributed to the choice of using the Construct 2/Construct 3 game engine/toolset.  This is a very poor quality toolset sometimes used by amateur developers as it doesn't require advanced game development skills, but unfortunately has very limited capabilities (it's worse than GameMaker Studio!).  Just as you can't make a silk purse out of a sows ear, you can't make a great video game if you use a terrible engine.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

You don't have to take my word about how bad the game is, we can measure the interest in a game by how much people bothered to play it.  VERLIES II has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game absolutely failed to capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for starting the game, but less than 8 percent of players bothered to even do that.  That's a tiny, tiny proportion of gamers who even bothered with this.  Ouch.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this isn't consistent with the achievement stats, that show less than 8 percent of players bothered playing the game at all.  How is it possible for this game to have so many concurrent players who weren't even playing the game?  Trading cards.  Players will use card idling software to collect the cards and sell them, but this won't trigger any achievements in-game.  That tells us people only really bought this game for trading cards, and that's a damning indictment of the woeful quality.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

VERLIES II is relatively cheap at $3 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.  If you're looking for a good dungeon crawler retro RPG, you can get the old Eye of the Beholder games on Steam, or the slick retro Legend of Grimrock games.  Try those instead.

review:
This game is awesome and easy to play, very sensible and focused. One of the best dungeon crawlers I've played in a while. 

The main game, Verlies II, is an excellent game. It is structured in a way that provides excellent, streamlined challenge, opportunities to notice one's own player mistakes and integrate them into future playthroughs, and an easy to use, easy to understand interface. It isn't the 'standard' control interface, but it is more streamlined than the 'standard' control interface.  It didn't take too long before I turned "show intro" to off and "fast dice game" to on--this game's mechanics are simple, delightful, and their integration leads to a very elaborate experience that requires thought, consideration, and choice, and consideration of the game's structure. I can easily see how some players rack up hundreds of hours playing VERLIES II. It does what it does, better than most games do what most games do.

It offers two primary variations from the normal, default difficulty: "I'm a p*ssy" difficulty is the first one. I did an attempt on this difficulty between attempts on normal. This alternative, reduced difficulty variation features 'hide 'n' heal' mechanics and some items and services with lower prices. It may feature other differences, that's what I first noticed. The second primary variation is a DLC called VERLIES: Origins, a port of VERLIES I. 

Verlies: Origins is a lot like Verlies II, but it doesn't have the hub town and instead you find various people within the dungeons who offer various services. It also doesn't have the blocking mechanic, that I am aware of--right-click used the equipped magic, instead. If there's another button to block in Verlies Origins, I didn't find it. The first variation is good for exploring potential skill development, because you'll survive longer with HP regeneration and in theory can acquire more skill points faster than on normal difficulty. Verlies Origins is a game that some prefer to Verlies II, some don't. Verlies II is enough of a structural change that it's even more different than the change between Dragon Quest Monsters to Dragon Quest Monsters 2. 

VERLIES Origins is a well put together game, also. It shares structural similarities with VERLIES II, and exhibits structural differences. Origins is a much more forgiving game than VERLIES II. I played it before I played VERLIES II, so I could see where VERLIES II came from.

review:
This game is addicting.
Really. I like its simplicity, graphic style, the combat mechanics and character progression.
Everything blends together to create a nice and gripping experience that, altogether, is more than the sum of the parts.

So why the thumb down?

It is simply too random. After a few starts, you realise when you will gonna pass the first level and weather you'll make to the third.
Once you got hold of the timing mechanics, there isn't much more in strategy you can do against monsters: if the game is terse enough in providing gold or useful equipment... that's it. Start again.

Even sleeping in the inn is 50gp, most probably you will not have that sum for the first three level, and only by selling useful equipment.

The major problem, though, is the blocking mechanic where you still take damage.
That is completely out of the player control; if you don't get money or equipment to resell, you'll not get a better shield soon enough to save precious health.

And that is the second main issue: you'll be replay the first two/three level ad nasueam hoping in a bit of luck in the found treasure.

All in all, from a compelling and fun game, it is bored down to a grind where you hope the "dungeon" to be generous enough to allow you progress the game.

review:
Рекомендовать ли игру? Не знаю. Может какому-то любителю пермасмерти. Я в принципе не люблю игры рассчитанные на довольно долгое прохождение, в которых при этом отсутствует сохранение хоть в каких-то точках. Даже Darkest Dungeon этим подбешивает. Но там хотя бы загубив партию прокаченных героев не теряешь весь прогресс. А здесь, умер - начинай с нуля. И кроме обычной смерти в подземелье, можно запороть прохождение проигравшись в кости в городе. Прохождение то тут линейное, и если дошёл до босса на уровне, едва не погиб, но успел отступить и вернулся в город, то перед новой попыткой надо восстановиться за деньги и докупить склянок здоровья. А денег нафармить негде, можно только попытать удачу сыграв в кости. Но шансы выиграть в кости - 50 на 50. Ну может, если у тебя есть система, то 60 на 40. У меня такое впервые, что буквально снимаешь последнюю рубашку, чтобы отыграться, и если не повезёт - начинай игру с начала. Лучше уж вообще не трогать эту мини игру. Тем более, она нарочно растянута по времени. Но денег всегда не хватает, потому что в магазине всегда есть что купить полезного.

В остальном, боёвка - 2d враг как в тире ездиет из угла в угол, с почти постоянной переодичностью атакует. Вам надо нажимать в нужные моменты лкм (удар) и пкм (блок), Е и R (выпить пузырёк), 1-4 (применить выбранный скилл). У меня отторжения не вызывает, так же как и прокачка, хотя это не то, к чему я привык. Передвижение и взаимодействие с предметами, честно говоря, на 2+. Но привыкнуть можно. Всё равно, в игре есть некая атмосферность и может затянуть. Карту могли бы нарисовать покрасивее, а то выбивается из стилистики.

Хотелось бы поставить палец вверх, но недотянивает.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006784126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 400, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1544715856}
review:
Verlies II (v1.2.1a)

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1588521726

[b]POSITIVES[/b]

+ diverse Talente, darunter aktive und passive
+ 7 weitere Helden freischaltbar

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1588522876

[b]NEGATIVES[/b]

- keine Charaktererschaffung, lediglich ein vorgefertigter Char bei Spielbeginn
- furchtbare Grafik bei der sich die besiegten Gegner in gelbe und rote Flöckchen auflösen
- fehlen jeglicher Animationen
- angezogene Ausrüstung wird grafisch nicht dargestellt
- wirklich miese Soundeffekte die sich eher befremdlich anhören
- lediglich auf Englisch
- Tastatur nicht frei belegbar
- bei den schlecht umgesetzten Kämpfen kann man lediglich Schlagen und Blocken (und später Zaubern), wobei der Gegner vor einem rumzuckelt und sich dabei nach links und rechts bewegt, um zu erschweren dass man ihn mit der Maus anvisieren kann
- zufallsgenerierte Dungeons, die diese Bezeichnung nicht verdienen
- minimalistiche Karte

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1588521875

[b]FAZIT[/b]

Verlies II ist eine Zumutung aus dem Jahr 2015, wobei es technisch eher aus dem vorherigen Jahrhundert zu stammen scheint. Die Bilder der Gegner und auch sonst alles im Spiel, sehen aus, als hätte man im Bildbearbeitungsprogramm einfach einen Comic-Filter drüber gelegt um zu kaschieren wie hässlich das Ganze eigentlich ist. 
Die Verliese bestehen lediglich aus zufällig aneinandergrenzte Quadrate mit ebenfalls zufällig platziertem Loot. In jedem „Raum“ kann man sich in vier Richtungen drehen, wobei im Grunde jeder Raum gleich aussieht, eben nur mit was anderem drin. 
Die „Kämpfe“ reduzieren sich darauf dass man mit der Maus das Ziel anklickt und nach einer abgezählten Anzahl an Treffern auch mal mit dem Schild pariert um nicht den vollen Schaden zu erhalten. Langweiliger und vor allem unspannender geht’s kaum. Am Ende eines jeden Verlieses wartet immer ein Endgegner und ein Durchgang zum nächsten zufallsgenerierten Verlies wobei sich nach einiger Zeit auch mal das Setting ändert.
Zurück in der Stadt kann man zum Händler, Schmied, Tempel oder in die Taverne gehen um danach gleich wieder ins nächste, gleiche Verlies zu tappen. Eine Geschichte gibt es nicht, und wenn man stirbt, was stets einen permanenten Tod darstellt, wird man vom Spiel auch noch verhöhnt und ist gezwungen wieder ganz von vorne anzufangen.
Dieses Spiel untertraf aller meine Erwartungen und ist wirklich niemandem zu empfehlen. Spielt besser einen richtigen grid-based Dungeon Crawler und versteckt das Spiel im tiefsten Verlies das ihr finden könnt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1536884739}
review:
"Verlies II" ist ein klassischer Dungeon-Crawler mit zufällig generierten Leveln und Permadeath.

Mechanisch erinnert alles an alte Zeiten, als wäre man auf einem Amiga unterwegs. Wir starten in einer Stadt, die mehrere Screens bereithält. Wir haben zum Beispiel eine Kneipe, einen Händler oder einen Schmied. In der Kneipe können wir schlafen und uns so regenerieren oder auch mit einer Würfelpartie Gold gewinnen. Beim Händler können wir naürlich handeln und uns beim Schmied Waffen herstellen lassen. 

Und wir können von hieraus den ersten Dungeon betreten. Dort bewegen wir uns Screen für Screen weiter, treffen auf Gegner wie Fledermäuse Schlangen oder auch mal nen Drachen. In Kisten, Körben und Vasen finden Gold, Heiltränke oder auch mal Equipment. Dabei ist der Dungeonlevel zunächst verdeckt. Erst durch das Erkunden wird die Struktur auf unserer Map sichtbar. Jeder Level hat einen Ausgang zu einem neuen Level eines neuen Dungeons. An dieser Stelle können wir uns immer entscheiden, ob wir in die Stadt gehen wollen, um zu regenerieren oder loot zu verkaufen oder gleich den nächsten Dungeon betreten, was uns einen  XP-Boost beschert. Mit Skill-Points können wir ziemlich viele Fähigkeiten verbessern. 

Der Kampf gegen Gegner funktioniert recht simpel. Mit der rechten Maustaste greifen wir an, schwingen zum Beispiel unser Schwert und mit der linken heben wir unser Schild, das uns teilweise vor gegnerischen Angriffen schützt.  

Das Spiel hat einige Ausrüstungsgegenstände wie Waffen, Schilde, Handschuhe, Rüstung und diverses anderes Zeugs. Ziemlich komplex und wie in diesem Genre üblich können wir Equipment auch nur ausrüsten, wenn wir das notwendige Level haben. Sterben wir, dürfen wir wieder von vorne anfangen.

Unser erster Charakter ist ein simpler Jüngling. Wenn wir bestimmte Voraussetzungen erfüllen können wir noch sieben weitere Charaktere freischalten. 

Das Game ist strukturell sehr oldschool, was sich auch durch den knackigen Schwierigkeitsgrad bemerkbar macht. Man wird immer wieder sterben. Vor allem auch dadurch, daß das Dungeon immer zufällig generiert wird, bedarf es auch einer gehörigen Portion Glück, um wirklich erfolgreich zu sein und weit zu kommen. Das wird für viele Spieler frustrierend sein, Genreerfahrene könnten aber gerade die Herausforderung mögen. Wenn man sich darauf einlassen kann, kann das Spiel nämlich durchaus Suchtpotential entwickeln. Auch wenn ich selber diese Suchtwirkung durchaus auch bemerken konnte, wurde es mir dann doch nach einiger Zeit zu anstrengend und zu repetetiv. Auch muß erwähnt werden, daß das Spiel durchaus mal abstürzen kann.

Ästhetisch löst das Game die Problematik eines offenkundig geringen Budgets durch einen interessanten comicrealistischen Look, der ungewöhnlich, aber durchaus passend wirkt.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
6/10 Atmosphäre
5/10 Story
6/10 Grafik
5/10 Sound
6/10 Spielmechanik
5/10 Balancing
6/10 Spielspaß

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Nur für frustresistente Oldschool-Dungeon-Crawler.

[h1][b]6/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198124738753', 'num_games_owned': 3683, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1396, 'last_played': 1524698890}
review:
Punishing, wicked roguelike gridbased dungeon crawler with active combat that requires timing, strategy and actually landing your mouse cursor on the enemies as you swing. Lots of ways to combine your skills and create the build you want. Has a few interesting puzzles, one at the end of each level. This game does all it can to work against you, so that you really do feel you accomplish something every time you make it just a little further. But there are many ways to die, and permadeath is what's at stake if you fail.

There are a few strange spellings and the people in the village speak in a rather odd manner but you can always understand what's being said. This is more about the dungeon crawling, with a very limited amount of text anyway so its not a big issue regardless. 

I never experienced any bugs/glitches/problems with the game and I really recommend it but its probably not for everyone. If a hard as nails, unforgiving, permadeath dungeon crawler that wants to do everything it can to assure you die, doesn't sound like something you'd want to subject yourself to then you won't enjoy this title. If you love grid movement dungeon dives and extremely punishing gameplay in that setting, Verlies II is worth playing.

I'd say the music, graphics and the like are passable but not great. Even so it has its charms and some of the enemies are absolutely ghastly, especially in the later levels.

I just beat the game for the first time with Neferon. However, he's incredibly overpowered if you know how to manage his gimmicks and quirks. But its not over for me as there are 7 other characters I can choose from and I know every single one of them will be a much harder victory than Neferon's was. That said, there is replayability for sure, for those that want to try to succeed with different strategies. There are lots of achievements to gather as well, but don't worry, you don't have to conquer Verlies II with every single player character to 100% the game. (That might not stop me from trying, though. :) )

author: {'steamid': '76561198053235831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1522283359}
review:
Игра представляет собой Might & Magic X: Legacy на минималках. Причём, на очень сильных минималках.
Проблемы данной игры:

1. Оптимизация. Она реально ужасна! Запуск игры занимает столь длительное время, что Вы можете скачать нормальную игру. Серьёзно. Прибавьте постоянные подвисания и безумно долгие переходы из меню в меню. Понижение качества графики с Low на Hight (да, их всего два) не меняет абсолютно ничего. Из-за подвисаний игра чаще всего представляет собой слайд-шоу. Ну и "вишенка на торте" - при открытии справки "How to play" в игре ничего не происходит, но, едва выйдя из игры, Вы обнаружите, что эта кнопка открывает РУКОВОДСТВО в стиме!

2. Баланс - вторая проблема. Его реально нет: Вы спокойно убиваете боса, огромного огра, проходите дальше и мрёте от простой слабой летучей мыши, потомучто она атакует Вас исключительно станящими атаками, и Вы ничего, абсолютно НИЧЕГО не можете сделать в ответ. Ну или другой пример: отравление в первом подземелье - фатально. Смиритесь: противоядий у Вас нет, вернуться в город и купить его Вы, почему-то не можете, всё, что Вам остаётся - грести на врагов в тщетной попытке получить спасительный лут. В начальных локациях эта попытка, действительно, тщетна. Смиритесь.

3. Графика. Не обманывайтесь, на скриншотах представлены наиболее хорошие кадры. В самой игре полно по-настоящему ужасно нарисованных противников. Да что там, взгляните только на представленного персонажа (Chinк)! Без слёз смотреть просто невозможно, "мультяшный" стиль не спасает. Анимацию атак, кстати, тоже не завезли.

Можно и дальше расписывать все минусы этой неиграбельной поделки, но лаконичней сказать одно слово: халтура. Халтура, в которую невозможно играть и которая, почему-то, стоит 250 рублей. 

Потратьте эти деньги лучше на что-нибудь более качественное!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055725979', 'num_games_owned': 1326, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 2286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1937, 'last_played': 1499090402}
review:
En su grado más dimensional son partidas rápidas de supervivencia y roguelike que se estructuran por 28 niveles de mazmorra así en plan pozo. Una vez accedamos a un nivel inferior de la mazmorra, con su consiguiente boss como desafío último, el nivel anterior quedará cerrado para siempre. Un pueblo servirá de base de control para descansar, reponer pociones, visitar al herrero o comprar al mercader equipamiento y llaves para los cofrecillos cerrados que es donde está el buen botín.

El pilar del juego serían sus combates. Son contra un monstruo, un sprite en movimiento de zigzag y en un tiempo real que actua funcionalmente como una combinación para establecer dos tipos de jugabilidades bien distintas bajo un mismo sistema de reglas. Principalmente estos combates habrá que dominarlos en su grado elemental, atacando con la espada tantas veces como podamos mientras bloqueamos con el escudo la frecuencia de los ataques enemigos. A partir de dominar esto conseguiremos reducir mucho la perdida de vida para afrontar todos los monstruos que se nos pongan por delante al entrar en las salas, estas tendrán un 35% más o menos de posibilidad de encuentro contra monstruo. La vida no se recupera y en su grado más existencial es la que soporta la mayor carga del equilibrio general.

Los datos del sistema de reglas para los combates son unos cuantos por ataque: los puntos de armadura, % de crítico, dodge, resistencia mágica, redución de daño por bloqueo, puntos de estamina y su recuperación por segundo, velocidad del arma entre 1 y 100 siendo 100 el doble de rápido, y por último daño del arma y la estamina que consume; si agotamos la estamina necesitaremos un segundo extra para empezar a recuperarla.

Para poner en práctica estos combates en primera persona en tiempo real de milisegundos se crean muchos tipos de enemigos o sprites en movimiento a los que se le anula la estadística del dodge para realizarla manualmente sobre el sprite, de esta forma se creará una esquiva para el enemigo basada en nuestra habilidad, bastante interesante. Los enemigos tendrán una frecuencia de ataque y será muy importante establecer golpes consecutivos fijos entre sus ataques.
A esto le sumamos muchos tipos de monstruos diferentes y una velocidad de ataque que puede variar a tres tipos entre las mismas clases, esto refuerza su pilar ya comentado en estudiar al enemigo en tiempo real para determinar su velocidad contra la nuestra.
En los tres primeros niveles nos encontraremos enemigos como las serpientes verdecillas que pueden envenenar si consiguen encajarte un ataque, con lo que por voluntad propia manejaremos una situación de prevención en intentar bloquear todos sus ataques como tema principal; el envenenamiento es uno de los factores jodidos que abortará la misión en curso para tener que ir al pueblo a curarnos.
Nos podemos encontrar también ratas gigantes muy duras, bandidos o murciélagos, estos ultimos débiles aunque pueden aturdirte si no bloqueas, enganchandote seguidamente un montón de ataques consecutivos. Un boss por ejemplo puede llegar a aturdirte al principio y matarte sin poder hacer nada.

Posteriormente se crea un mapa dispuesto en cuadrícula de salas cuadriculadas con accesos entre ellas por los lados que actuará de escenario para la configuracion y establecimiento de elementos hacia nuestra movilidad y desarrollo.
Más o menos en el 35% de las salas podrá haber enemigos y al entrar tendremos que realizar el combate; y desde aquí hasta su limpieza del mapa se establecerá una medida de la cantidad de puntos de vida que vamos perdiendo. Se supone que tenemos que ganar experiencia para adquirir habilidades y también conseguir botín de las salas, de la forma más estable posible en lo que refiere a la perdida de vida
Al final del camino de salas existirá un boss que establecerá la verdadera medida de nuestro poder, esta medida sera el poder aguantarle sus ataques antes de caer derrotado.

El juego tiene la dificultad de una probabilidad digamos que agotadora, con lo que cualquier decisión que tomemos será llevada a su punto más estricto. Propone una ficha de héroe con 8 tipos de equipamiento de armadura, escudo y arma, además, cuenta con tres ramas de habilidades para montar un montón de arquetipos de tipos de héroe. Se trata de un personaje que sube niveles o evoluciona completamente hacia sus posibilidades de supervivencia, con lo que el juego se distancia del género rol para envolverse en la supervivencia extrema de la probabilidad con un matiz roguelike: aunque libremente y con muchas posibilidades, estamos forzados a lo que el juego dicta, y las reglas son duras.

Matemáticamente tiene un sistema cerrado bastante diferente a lo visto que ni es acumulativo ni es estable. Se basa en una medida o media entre un número alto de eventos y una fluctuación importante de los mismos, esto en base a su estructura, probabilidad y combates en tiempo real. Por ejemplo nuestro ataque con la espada realiza un daño apróx de 4 de 24, en el cual estableceremos una medida apróx de 13 para mil ataques. A esto se le suma la fluctuación importante debido por ejemplo a la cantidad de combates que vamos a realizar, en la que en uno de ellos podremos tener perfectamente dos errores que pueden costarnos que la partida termine.

El juego es un vicio aunque es difícil que salga una partida buena y muchísimo menos mantener la estabilidad durante 28 niveles que se complican más que bien.
El problema de esto también es el desconocimiento de los bosses y enemigos nuevos que vamos encontrando, que nos harán morir muchas veces antes de empezar a conocerlos para tratarlos adecuadamente.

review:
DOS時代の名RPG群、その系譜を受け継げなかったクソゲーです。
疑似3Dダンジョンを左クリックの攻撃と右クリックの防御で抜けていくレトロスタイル自体は尊いのですが、ゲームバランスに対する配慮が無さ過ぎます。
最初のダンジョンのツモと敵の種類が全てです。ここで運が悪いと資金繰りで浮かぶこともなくどん詰まりになります。
他のランダム生成系RPGは様々な迂回路を設けて破綻を防ぐのですが、このゲームの場合序盤のプレイスタイルに選択の余地がなく、
罠が連続してもダメ手数で押す敵に集られてもダメ宝箱からまとまった金が出なくてもダメ……と、プレイヤーの所作を無意味にするハードルが目白押しです。
難しいと理不尽は似て非なるものです。何より楽しさにおいて天と地の開きがあります。
このゲームをプレイしていると、その想像を絶する運ゲーっぷりにだんだん無表情になりますよ。

author: {'steamid': '76561198137933363', 'num_games_owned': 2782, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1473570718}
review:
序盤、ダンジョン内に果物バケツ(回復アイテム)が何個落ちているか、ある程度まとまった金が拾えるか、ボス前に敵に何体遭遇して滞りなくレベルアップできるか、その遭遇する敵が嫌らしい相手じゃないか、などなど果てしなくランダム生成運頼みのゲームバランス。アイテムやゴールドや敵の引き次第で、大部分のプレイが4階層くらいまでの間で簡単に(プレイスキルに関係なく)「詰む」。

操作は単純だが工夫の余地があまりなく、防御の合間に斬ってたまに回復するだけの戦闘。面白みのない戦闘は一応退却という選択肢があったりするものの、倒さなかった敵は同じグリッドで必ずまたエンカウントするし序盤のダンジョンはほとんど一本道なので倒さないと結局先に進めない。

一度敵を倒して探索した場所に敵が湧いたりはしないので退却して後戻りしてもレベル上げやアイテム稼ぎできるわけでもなく、つまり逃げる選択肢の存在意義がない。街に戻ることも出来るが装備にしろ宿にしろ高いのでダンジョンを攻略できずに帰ったところで結局ジリ貧になるだけ。万事がこの調子で行動の選択肢が狭いため戦略性がない。

宝箱や設置物を調べようとすると低確率で発動するトラップ。事前に調べたり避ける手段もなく、物資が手に入らなければ結局詰むので開けないという選択肢はないのだから、結局ダメージを受ける可能性を折り込んだ上でトラップを引かないことを祈るしかない。操作性が悪い上にキーバインドも変えられないし不親切なインターフェース。クイックリスタートが全然クイックじゃないなどストレス要素満載。

3,4階層あたりからは多少行動に選択肢が持てるようになってきて、これでやっと「ゲーム」が始まるって感じなので、実質そのへんがスタートと考えるとそこにたどり着くまでがありえないほど運ゲー。オープニングあるいはチュートリアルの間に問答無用で10回中9回殺されるゲームみたいなのを思い浮かべてくれれば大体あってます。

上記だけでも既にくっそつまらんサムズダウン確定って感じだが、極めつけは「超絶運ゲーの序盤をようやく抜けてやっと行動に選択肢が出始めた」という所でわりと頻繁に発生するクラッシュ(最初からやり直し。パーマデスゲームなので途中セーブからやり直すとかもありません。せめてクラッシュ対策のバックアップセーブくらいしてくれよ)

Steamでは600本超のゲームを購入しており、ゲー無状態のアチーブメントスパムやネタにもならないレベルのクソゲーも少なからず引いていますが、返金お願いしたのは今の所「そもそもゲームになってない」と感じたこの一本だけです。仮に100円のゲームなら自分の審美眼のなさに甘んじただろうけど、期待と内容のギャップが余りにもひどすぎた。

[i]このレビューが役立ったなら、ぜひ「参考になった」ボタンを押してください。また、他にも様々なゲームを [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/26084475-Suizin/]Steamキュレーターにて[/url] 紹介しています。[/i][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198044923847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1468039905}
review:
I saw someone beat it and the developer actually said congrats. This was after people complaining it was hard and so forth. So much so that I had to try it, the amount of "talk" about this game sold me.

[b]This is what I liked[/b]:
The game felt immersive, it's small and not built by some huge studio but the maker captured a pretty cool feeling with it for me. The art, the ambiance, the lone dungeon hole before you go inside. Heck the finding of a pick ax in a shadow of the wall. Ohhhh I like this, I can feel myself in the game, lost in this dungeon. I enjoy this.

The game makes you feel as if your all alone having come to some small town on the verge of nowhere to find only a handful of small time town's people who can offer basic aid. But the best feeling is leaving town to that lone dungeon, just sitting there all silent with just the sounds of the surrounds begging you to come inside and explore.

I feel also that the developer of the game is around and adding stuff to the game making me wonder what is to come next and that is exciting!

[b]What I was meh on[/b]:
Yep it's hard, the death comes fast and starting over is fun for a bit, then sucks as you want to progress but find you die and lose that run. The enemies hit your shield and you still take too much damage, while your rewarded for blocking, I didn't feel it was enough and died to fights I should not have, as I had a nice rhythm going on slash, block, slash.

The Modding (I am going to call this what it is, replacing core files with your own art or music or words) is fun for silly things, like making a pic you like the new intro, but it's not true modding, it's just changing the interface for funzies. One use of this I want to try to play with is to see if I can change the main character (as characters are unlock able this might not work), but will see in time if I can do this.

review:
1. See game in the Store. Art looks great. It's a roguelike? I'm in!

2. See mixed reviews. What are they complaining about? Difficulty too hard? No problem! Unskippable intro animation? Boo! Annoying puzzle minigame? Ugh. Needless delays in the dice game? Boo!

3. See patch notes. The developer has fixed all the complaints! You can now turn off the unskippable animation, skip the minigame, and play the dice game instantly. Wow!

4. Realize that this is a developer that cares about the players and responds to community feedback. Realize that the issues raised in the negative reviews have been fixed. Yay!

5. Buy game at full price.

6. Play game. It's fun. Horray!

7. Game crashes. Boo!

8. Restart game? Nope. Game leaves some processes running and won't restart.

9. Reboot.

10. Restart game? Yes!

11. Play game. It's still fun. Horray!

12. Game crashes. Won't restart. Reboot. Restart game. Crash. Reboot. Crash. Reboot.

13. Request refund.
developer_response:
There are very few complaints about crashes, often it's directx or graphics drivers that are outdated.

I remain at your service via mail or Steam forum.

review:
これは面白い！
キーアサインが一見妙なのと、変更不可能な点、動く敵にカーソルを合わせないと攻撃が当らない点、防御をしてもダメージを喰らう点、スタミナが切れると手出しできない点、各層のボスを倒しても先へ進む為には見づらい鍵やシークレットを探し出さなければならない点、徐々に罠や敵の攻撃がいやらしくなり、状態異常も致命的になっていく点等々、全てが挑戦的でプレイヤーを潰しにかかってくるスタンスを剥き出しにしたFPPアクションRPG。
キャラビルドはスキル取得型で選択が要となるが、アイテムの引きによっても大きく左右される。
金策を重視する余りギャンブルに手を染めるプレイヤーも多い様だが・・・果たして全18層クリアなるか？

プレイヤーの熟練度とゲーム内キャラの成長がシンクロしないと徐々に追い詰められ圧殺されるだけとなる。
にも関わらず、チュートリアルやイージーな導入展開が一切無い所謂 "死んで憶えろ型" だが、遊ぶにつれそれが非常にマッチしていると感じる様になり、操作が板についた物となる頃からますます熱中する

ローグライクやダンマスクローンに分類されているが、それぞれの傾向的特徴である雑多性やギミック偏重に依らず独自のフィーリングとすっきりしたゲームデザインを併せ持っており、難易度の高さと上手く絡み合った好作品。

review:
In the approximate 13 minutes I played this game, I found it to be entertaining to say the least. I can tell you that this game is not for everyone, but for the few out there, it is worth a try. I find the graphics to be gorgeous, even though they aren't pretty by todays standards. 
     One annoying part of the game, and yes, i have to mention it, is lack of any kind of tutorial. The opening of the dungeon, at least in my game, the first doorway looked like an open hole in the wall, but I couldn't traverse it. Only upon accidently scrolling my mouse over it did i realize i had to press the "F" key of the keyboard. An option for keybindings might help. 
     As I have only played roughly 13 minutes of the game, I didn't delve too heavily into all the options. I will be playing more in the future and will update this review as I go along. I am a huge fan of Indie games as well as mainstream. I had read many reviews on the game before purchasing it, and it d\saddens me to think that people put some much emphasis on how a game looks graphically, that they fail to see any kind of challenge. I love the tought, time and effort someone took to make this game. Thank you Koya Games for this gem, I enjoy it and I hope many others will too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198014624299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1444239582}
review:
The word "ruthless" used in the description of the game is just a euphemism for minimal game development and lazy programming. I rank this worst than Coldfire Keep. For $10 USD I didn't expect much, but I got less than that. Maybe this is one of those games that's meant to be played on mobile device. Here are the pros and cons as I see them:

PROS: 
1) Nice graphics for still scenes
2) Interface is pretty straight forward and intuitive

CONS:
1) Saving game. 
    a) quits the game and not back to main menu. 
    b) If you die, and you will, you go to the main menu. If you choose Continue you go to the point where you died and go into an endless loop. Start a new game.

2) If you get poisoned by a snake, unless you have a Cure Poison potion (50gp), you will die. You die because, even if you sell the two mana potions you start with you only get 30gp. If you get poisoned you CANNOT leave the dungeon to get cured back in town. Since you don't have a Cure Poison potion, YOU DIE!

3) No resting or camping. No regeneration of health unless you find food. Good luck on finding potions as the dungeon is randomly generated, so the map changes in each game. If you get poisoned, YOU DIE!

4) There is not enough money or junk to be gathered to afford buying/upgrading gear or a single Cure Poison potion. And, we know what happens if you get poisoned....

5) Oh, but wait....find a chest or two that requires a key. Didn't loot anything that yielded a key? Maybe go back to town to buy one, but you can't because you can't leave the dungeon. Ok, move forward to the next room, and dammit another snake. CRAP, the character got poisoned! Guess what? That's right, YOU DIE!

This could have been a fun and interesting game, but the developer didn't seem to want to be bothered including a few features to allow the game to be interesting and challenging versus just ridiculous to the point of why should I spend anymore time on a unenjoyable $10 game.

After killing bosses on a dungeon floor you have to play an annoying pixel hunting minigame of find the gem or pickaxe or stone in a wall to continue. author: {'steamid': '76561198164755422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1443761503}
review:
Just requested a REFUND. The dev seriously needs to re-think how certain aspects of the game should work. 

As for being a difficult game, I can live with that, Shite I grew up playing Wizardry I on the Apple IIe and then the PC, talk about unforgiving and difficult? I beat that game multiple times and it was very difficult compared to today’s games.

The problem with Verlies II is NOT it's gameplay difficulty, but the ridiculous and annoying controls, plus highly illogical rules that limit the player. Let me explain.

1. Using the 'F' key to move forward instead of the standard 'W' key as in most games, you know the WASD control.

When you are in the dungeon, you face one of four possible directions just like in most other games of this type, yet to move forward you HAVE to focus your cursor over the opening and then press F and not W, that is ridiculous! Now, saying that... IF the opening in front of the hero had something like a shut, or locked door, then placing the cursor over it, and pressing 'F' to unlock (if you have a key), or to turn the knob to open a door would be understandable, but so far in the time I played, all the openings are simple black passages to simulate the darkness leading into the next chamber. Since the openings are unobstructed and as easy as walking from one room in your house to the next via an arch or opening, a simple press of the 'W' key to move forward would suffice. Also, if perhaps a single direction had more than a single exit, or path/door then placing the cursor over the proper door, or opening you wish to exit through makes sense, but in all the time I've played I've only seen a single opening/path in any one direction. Again a simple press of 'W' would suffice.

2. Exiting the Dungeon

When you enter the dungeon, you CAN NOT simply turn around and exit, even though when you do turn around, you see the cavern exit and the forest (trees, grass, etc..) on the other side of the exit. Essentially, there is nothing to keep you from simply turning around and walking out, especially if you've wandered around a bit and took a beating and need to get back to town for supplies or to heal. When you try to leave you get some BS excuse that you have too much pride to leave the dungeon. COME ON! If you are really set on such a ridiculous rule (not allowing the hero to exit via the opening they just entered from, use a little imagination and get creative. For example... "You enter the dungeon and look about the first chamber. As you are examining the chamber you hear a deep, rumble... the room begins to shake and then a loud crash... then darkness! You spin around to see the entrance to the dungeon/cave has caved in and there is no amount of digging that would allow you to leave this place from whence you came! Tis up to thee hero to find another means of escaping this dunjon!" Wala, instant logical explanation and more realistic method for keeping a player from leaving the dunjon whenever he, or she wishes to.

3. No control customization!

How many games have you played where they use a modified WASD control scheme where Q and E actually turn you left, or right? Well, in this game, the 'E' key = drink a health potion. Do you know how many times I've been in the dunjon and tried to turn and my sub-conscious simply hit the 'E' key because two of the other games I play use the 'E' key to turn right? Well, it's safe to say I've wasted countless potions by accidentally hitting E instead of D to turn right. This can be simply remedied by allowing the user to customize their movement and function keys.

There are a few other issues that irk me... Here is one more...

4. Using a shield to block.

This game's combat is not turn based, but real time. The monster moves from left to right, and vice versa all the time you must position your cursor over the creature before swinging your weapon or you'll end up missing the target. Combat is really a timing game because you need to see how many strikes you can get in before you must press the other mouse button to raise your shield and defend the monster's attack. This so far is fine and can be quite enjoyable, but there is a problem in that even using the shield properly doesn't negate the damage taken by the monsters attack. It may lessen it, but if you are low on health, have no more health potions, and a simple hit or two is going to kill you, then you might as well restart because there is NOTHING you can do to survive the next encounter, and you aren;t going to move more than a room or two before that next encounter happens. Remember as per issue #2 above, you also can't turn around and head back to town and rest, heal, or stock up on supplies, so once you are in the situation just mentioned, your game is OVER even though you aren't quite dead yet. The next fight and a single hit or two regardless of whether blocked or not, ends up killing you. A better way to have implemented the shield would be one of the following...

A) Have the monsters movement and strike timing alternate between 1 or 2 speeds during a battle, so you can't simply get used to a creatures timing and then strike/block without danger of harm. With this method, you can have a shield block all damage from a strike that is successfully blocked with the shield. The slight randomness to a monster's attack pattern can trip up a player who may miss a block with the shield and thus the monster makes a hit that realistically kills the hero. That would be acceptable.

B) Have the shield only able to block a certain amount of strikes before the hero MUST repair it himself in the dunjon, or purchase a replacement shield to replace the now broken one. For this to work, the dev needs to either a) allow the hero to repair a shield with materials found in the dungeon, or b) Allow the hero the option of exiting the dunjon when he needs to go to town to have the smith repair or sell the hero a new shield.


Well, there are a few other things not worth mentioning because they will make this already long review even worse. I have requested a REFUND and will not purchase this game until some changes are made. I only hope the dev listens to this review and similar complaints in the forums and makes the right choices. I know I would have no problem returning to Verlies II, if these issues are remedied. As it is i would NOT recommend this game to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012990237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1416, 'last_played': 1707089526}
review:
When you rage quit from a game and you immediately want to give it another try, you know you've got something special.
Verlies II is a first person dungeon crawler, with real-time combat and grid based deplacement. 
And it wants you dead. 
Yep, according to the Master, death is the only thing you rightly deserve.
Let's prove him wrong, shall we?
In order to do that, you'll have to master combat precision, actively aiming at the monsters, and timing, to block with your shield and manage breath/endurance. It's a fun and solid system and you may soon try to block "frame perfect" in the vain hope it will mitigate more damage :p or you will die miserably for it was obvious this 5th strike in a row was dumb.
You'll have to master the odds in a game of dice for you'll need tons of money to buy keys, health potions, repair your so fragile stuff, cure poison, sharpen a blade, ID artefacts way too high level for you but rejoice! The smith can "standardize" it (remove the level restriction) for a mere 30 gold coins, less than a night at the inn! That's one of the only "gift" in an otherwise harsh and tight economy.
You'll have to take lots of risks. The boss is down, should you delve deeper straight away for an XP boost or should you take the chance to go back to town as it's the only moment it's free of charge? On the brink of death, do you tail back in the middle of a floor with XP loss or do you pick up that probably trapped healing basket? Yeah, you should have trekked back...
You'll have to die, over an over, for there's no tutorial and the game is mean and nasty. But like in the best rogue-likes where exploration and experimentation are key, it wraps up in the long run and I dare say Verlies really shines, carrying the torch of classics with strength.
You'll probably have to specialize. There's not so many level ups and there's a lot of skills, actives and passives. Classics like shield bashing or alchemy for instance, and not so classic ones, like a heal paid by XP or an instant kill spell that eats up your total mana pool. 
Floors layout, monster population, loot and traps are all randomly (procedurally?) generated. Level tone and design change every 3 floors and while there's no lush vistas nor DX12 features, the comic-style graphics are lovely (though I miss the naked blacksmith from the first opus^^)! Sound is good, atmospheric and creepy, or dumb and funny like that cash register trading sound.

So, this review's a mess... I hope it stills shows of much I enjoy this love letter to the genre! 
I cannot recommend it enough. Two blue thumbs up out of a puddle of blood. 
N'cha!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993455425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1350, 'last_played': 1571329245}
review:
Verlies 2 is a good game. It's not for everyone though, for mulitple reasons :
-It's a rogue-like, with permadeath. You die -> you retry.
-You CAN SAVE, but you only save your actual run, if you die you must restart from the beginning.
-It's HARD, and you must learn to play without any help.
-Game mecanisms remind A LOT old games with raw gameplay.
-Comics-style graphics, you love it or you hate it.
-English is approximate... but the developper apologize with humor and self mockery.

Well then, why is it good ?
-the game is hard, so when you finally learn how to play, it's very rewarding.
-Looting is very fun. Each item found has a value. You can equip or sell it (and more). The economy is great. Gold has an actual and vital value, unlike in many hack and slashes.
-Levelling offers a lot of variety with multiple skills.
-Crafting, weapon enhancements...
-You play, you crawl trough the dungeon, you die "WTF I STILL HAD 5 LIFE POTIONS WHAT A DUMB DIPSHIT I AM §§", you restart. I guarantee it. Verlies 2 is this kind of a game, "what if I made just another run ?" And another one, and another one... It's addictive.

review:
[b]VERLIES II[/b] is a hardcore dungeon crawler with a very interesting art style and an addictive combat system. 

In this game, timing is everything. You must attack, defend, use skills, and potions at the right moment because each enemy has its own attack timing. Mastering this aspect is crucial for survival. Any mistake can lead to certain death! Additionally, having a good build is vital, so make wise choices when leveling up and selecting skills.

The game offers a high level of challenge. If you die, it's game over, and you'll lose all your gold, XP, skills, and items. You'll have to start anew in a randomly generated dungeon. Furthermore, the dungeon presents various puzzles that you must solve to progress.

If you like challenging games, VERLIES II is highly recommended!



Review em Português

[b]VERLIES II[/b] é um dungeon crawler hardcore com um estilo artístico bem interessante e um sistema de combate viciante. 

Você deve atacar, defender, usar habilidades e poções no momento certo, já que cada inimigo tem seu próprio tempo de ataque, e dominar isto é muito importante para sobreviver. Se você cometer algum erro, será uma morte quase certa! Ter uma boa "build" também é muito importante, lembre-se disso ao escolher as skills corretas quando você subir de nível.

Este jogo é muito desafiador: se você morrer, já era, você perde todo o seu ouro, XP, habilidades e itens, e você vai ter que começar tudo de novo, em uma nova dungeon gerada aleatoriamente. Além disso, existem alguns quebra-cabeças que você deve resolver para avançar.

Se você gosta de jogos desafiadores, VERLIES II é muito recomendado!

review:
Ce jeu me trolle! Fichus pièges et damnés poisons, vous avez provoqué ma perte de trop nombreuses fois!

Et pourtant je trouve le jeu cool. La plupart des parties que j'ai perdues l'ont été par excès de confiance et autres maladresses pendant les combats. On apprend petit à petit à mettre toutes les chances possibles de son coté. Et ça fini par passer. Sauf quand on a vraiment pas de bol. Cher développeur, si t'as les oreilles qui siffent durant les prochains mois, j'en serai en partie à l'origine.

Je note aussi un réel effort sur la partie sonore, ça a l'air basique dit comme ça mais c'est une réelle aide à l'immersion.

Par contre l'ergonomie n'est pas au top. Rien d'insurmontable, on fini par s'y habituer, mais si il y a des modifs à faire c'est de ce coté là. Une option pour reatribuer les touches serait vraiment la bienvenue.

En bref un jeu que je recommande à ceux qui ne craignent pas la difficulté (et les développeurs sadiques).

review:
Voilà un excellent dungeon crawler sans concession ! 

Un petit bijou sadique et hautement addictif.

Sans aucune concession, vous allez rager, vous enerver, peut etre meme envoyer un gros ALT+F4 dans un acces de colere.

Mais au final vous le relancerez. Encore et encore.

Deja le gameplay est ultra dynamique, les combats, en temps reels, demandent de la concentration et un timing parfait. Chaque erreur, chaque faute d'inattention se paye soit cash soit au combat suivant.

Du coup, le jeu peut paraitre injuste et donner le sentiment d'etre insurmontable. Sauf que non, les runs suivants deviennent plus facile tant la suite est encore plus dure. 
Et à force de perseverance, j'ai vraiment le sentiment, tres gratifiant, de mieux maitriser. Jusque au combat suivant qui se termine mal... Le trop plein de confiance en soi coute cher, trop cher.

Alors c'est certain ce jeu n'est pas fait pour tout le monde.

Mais si vous avez envie d'un dungeon crawler joliment réalisé, dur, gratifiant alors il est fait pour vous !!

J'y retourne de ce pas !

author: {'steamid': '76561197981230326', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1445287740}
review:
VERLIES 2 est un jeu avec un concept intéressant.
Je pense que ce type de jeu avec génération des lvl et des items totalement aléatoire a un gros potentiel, personellement c'est un genre que j'aime beaucoup, surtout quand la difficulté est au rendez-vous.

Tous les ingrédients sont la: Loots aleatoire générés façon diablo, combats difficiles, possibilité de craft, d'enchanter, différents builds possibles, stats détaillées sur la feuille de personnage, etc... On a même des personnages à débloquer petit à petit par des moyens encore inconnus.

Malgré tout ça j'ai eu une experience négative avec ce jeu...
En effet le créateur a eu la bonne idée de mettre en place des "mini-énigmes" à la fin de chaque niveau, quand on a battu le boss. Alors autant j'aime quand un jeu me mène la vie dure, autant il faut que ce soit fait de manière ludique.
Parce que là, les fameuses "énigmes" consistent souvent à trouver un objet caché dans une pièce marque d'un "?" sur la carte (avec des variantes). Et c'est la ou un joueur normalement constitué peut devenir fou.

Le dernier run que j'ai fait, tout se passait bien, j'avais mitoné un build aux petits oignons, dropé de bons loots, trouvé un anneau unique, sauf qu'arrivé à une de ces fameuses énigmes, je suis resté bloqué 2h dans une pièce marqué d'un "?" à sonder chaque pixel à la recherche d'une gemme à placer dans une statue.
Au final j'ai fini par abandonner... parce que ça ne m'amusait pas du tout de rester bloqué entre 4 murs en bougeant ma souris partout, et je me suis rendu compte que j'avais passé la moitié de mon temps de jeu à chercher comme un demeuré. Je ne sais pas s'il s'agit d'un bug ou si je suis aveugle, mais abandoner mon run pour cette raison alors que mon personnage avait tout pour survivre me frustre au plus haut point. 

C'est vraiment dommage car sans ces énigmes casse-burne j'aurai aprécié ce jeu à sa juste valeur, mais cet aspect du jeu est juste une nuisance à mes yeux.. 
Des énigmes comme ça n'ont pas leur place dans un rogue-like. Pourquoi? parce que le but d'un rogue-like c'est de rerun à l'infini, l'aléatoire rendant chaque run unique, or les énigmes n'ont plus aucun intéret ludique une fois que tu en es à ton 15ème run, elles devienent juste une perte de temps pour le joueur qui doit se les retaper encore et encore.

Je changerai d'avis sur le jeu si des modifications sont effectuées à ce niveau, mais en attendant j'ai toujours mon personnage bloqué au niveau -4, je n'ai débloqué aucun des personnages cachés, et ayant passé autant de temps à m'énerver à cause de ces énigmes qu'à m'amuser, je ne suis pas satisfait de mon investissement de 10$.

Oui je suis dur, mais quand on demande aux joueurs 10$ pour un jeu aussi simpliste, il faut être irréprochable.

review:
Really fun game, it's a grid-based (I guess you would call it that) dungeon crawler with real-time combat and randomly-generated dungeon floors, enemy placement and items (as far as I can tell).

It's easy to learn the basics and get into, but is quite difficult and really unforgiving - it is also perma-death.

There's a fair amount of skills to level which is good and there's a town with various vendors and services you can visit in-between dungeon floors if you wish.

Visually I think the game is fantastic and the music/sound effects are fine.

I've been enjoying it and am slowly working further into the dungeon, highly recommended if you're a fan of this sort of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015191515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 993, 'last_played': 1443872696}
review:
Verlies II est destiné aux joueurs qui n'ont pas froid aux yeux, puisque le héro principal Chink ( Il y a plusieurs héros a débloquer de manières mystérieuses ) a pour compagnon de route La Mort. 
Vous vous dites pourquoi ça ? Et bien la raison est toute simple, Verlies II est dur, il est même très dur ! Car on y meurt trés souvent (c'est même un apprentissage me chuchotte Madanne La Mort ) , et ça veut dire, ce que cela veut dire, on recommence toute l'aventure depuis le debut et sans rien bien sur, c'est du même principe que The Blinding Of Isaac.

Et il n'est pas rare de mourir plusieurs fois contre des monstres tels que les chauves souris, serpents, lutins et autres horreurs ! 
Chaque monstres agissent différemments dans leurs façons d'attaquer, notamment sur leurs timings d'attaques, ou des effets aléatoires, et de bien d'autres maniéres.
Et vous connaitriez sans l'ombre d'un doute de nombreuse morts (j'en ai fais moi-même l'expérience) incalculable, dans la ligne de Dark Soul.

Car Verlies II n'est pas qu'un simple Dungeon Crawler ou là, il suffisait que d'avancer et de frapper bêtement les monstres. Nah ! Ici ça ne fonctionnera pas dans Verlies II !
J'avais commencé Verlies II en me disant " Facile, j'vais me le torcher rapidement ce jeu" mais il c'est avère, que la méthode traditionnelle des Dungeon Crawler ne fonctionnait pas !

Avec mes morts a répétitions, j'ai commencé a prendre Verlies II plus aux sérieux, et j'ai commencé a y réfléchir ou plutôt La Mort m'a poussé a jouer différemment et a apprendre de mes erreurs.
J'ai dans un premier temps appris a gérer plus correctement ma façon de jouer dans mes combats en me protégeant mieux et en frappant aux bons moments ( car oui les monstres on divers timings d'attaques, et c'est a nous de déterminer sa durée entre chaque coups et prendre en compte leurs deplacements variés au moment de la frappe ) , car il ne suffit pas que d'attaque pour gagner, la défense est tout aussi importante a notre survie. Et il y a aussi la gestion de notre stamina a prendre en compte, qui determinera les nombres de coups (qui est determiné par l'arme )
Autre subtilité voir plutôt de logique, le héro ne peut pas se soigner en même temps, qu'il frappe un monstre ! Autre point, il est primordiale de bien penser a l'évolution de son personnage dans les différentes capacités/aptitudes qu'on peut faire évoluer, et classer en 3 groupes et de 2 systèmes de Skill

-Art Fighting ce qui concerne les aptitudes des guerriers etc
-Magic Arcane ce qui concerne les magiciens etc
-Survival Talent ce qui concerne les voleurs etc

Pour chaque qu'une des classes, il y a 8 capacités (dont 24 en tout ) dans un système de Skill.

Le 1er est Active Skill, qui sont directement utilisablent, des boules de feu, des gros coups critiques, lancer de couteaux etc
Le deuxieme est le système Passive Skill au nombre de 12 et qui ont des effets permanents, comme améliorer des potions de soin, ou bien d'augmenter son esquive etc

Ce qui donnera beaucoup de possibilités a créer nos personnages a notre façon de jouer et de varier son gameplay ! Et Verlies II est riche pour ceci, car se créer un guerrier en utilisant sa vie , pour gagner des points d'expériences ( je n'ai jamais vu, d'autres jeux proposer cette capacité ) ou bien a faire un max de dommage, mais encore un magicien spécialisé dans l' herboriste et qui pourra se créer divers potions grâce aux herbes etc.

Un autre point important est l'argent. J'ai du apprendre a bien le gérer correctement ( ce n'est pas comme sur Diablo 3 avec 100 milliard en guise de décoration ) et a en gagner de différentes façons , en jouant au jeu de Dés , ou en revendant mes items trouvés .
L'argent a été ajusté correctement, il n'y en a jamais trop ou pas assez, ce qui nous poussera a bien réfléchir avant d'acheter un équipement, et a l'utiliser dans bien d'autres maniéres :

Inn, une auberges où on peut y dormir et apprendre des informations, mais également jouer aux dés
Merchant, pour acheter et vendre des équipements complètement gérés aléatoirements
Alchemist, pour acheter des potions
Black-smith, réparer, fabriquer, améliorer une arme, etc
Temple, permet d'enchanter des équipements, et d'identifier certains objets
Tout ces lieux sont importants pour tout aventuriers, alors je vous conseillerai de bien vous en servir et de les analyses, car c'est pour votre propre Salut :).

Une autre chose que j' ai apprécie beacoup, c'est le coté d'épée de damoclés, a la fin d'un donjon, a savoir deux choix qui nous sont proposé, a savoir :
continuer le donjon avec 50% d'experiences en plus sans pouvoir revenir au village ou bien revenir au village ( pour les soins et achats ) mais je ne profiterais pas du bonus d'experience. C'est une excellente façon de voir si on a les couilles pour gagner plus d'experiences en s'exposant d'avantage a la faucheuse :) !

Ensuite niveau de l'ambiance, les musiques sont agréables. Graphiquement le jeu est sympa mais c'est son ésthétique visuel ( dans un effet de BD comic a la Borderland ) très bien fait et nous font plonger sans problème dans cette grande aventure d'exploration. Verlie II offre des niveaux créent de façons completement aléatoires, dans des decors agréables et varier !

Pour conclure Verlies II a un grand potentiel dû a son gameplay élaboré par un système de Skill qui offre une liberté et une évolution totale aux joueurs, a concevoir son héro.
Une difficulté intelligente dans son systme de combat et de la gestions des ressources.
Verlies II donnera l'envie aux joueurs les plus téméraires de vouloir allez le plus loin possible dans le donjon, et de lui faire ressentir des sentiments comme la fierté, la joie, la puissance, et le good du challange accompli, mais aussi la rage de mourrir ahahaha ! 

Verlie II est une grande valeur et pour un prix dérisoire !

author: {'steamid': '76561198032291709', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1481361940}
review:
Bienvenue, aventurier ! Vous qui entrez, abandonnez toute espérance, comme dirait l'autre. Verlies 2 est, comme son nom l'indique, dans la pure lignée des dungeon crawler à l'ancienne (Dungeon Master, Wizardry, ...). Après avoir choisi votre personnage (deux bonnes poignées sont débloquables à ce jour), vous débutez en ville où vous trouverez tous les marchands habitués à s'en mettre plein les poches aux dépens des têtes brûlées dans votre genre.
Puis vous plongez sans même prendre de bain dans les tréfonds de Verlies. Enfin, vite dit, passer les premiers niveaux n'est déjà pas chose aisée, et les choix cornelliens. Vous progressez salle après salle, en plans fixes. Une carte se construit d'elle-même au fur et à mesure. Des choses à fouiller trainent. Vous pouvez seulement faire des quarts de tour pour franchir l'une des portes qui peut percer l'un des 4 murs.
Toutefois ce n'est pas du pur tour par tour. En effet, lorsque vous croisez un malotru, le combat se déroule en temps réel : vous cherchez à cliquer gauche pour refaire les dents du bougre qui se déplace sur l'écran, tout en cliquant droit pour se protéger au bouclier lorsqu'un coup vient. Il y a donc un réel apprentissage des patterns, des schémas suivis par chacun des adversaires rencontrés. Un vrai jeu de rythme, m'avancerais-je ! Des items aléatoires tombent alors, avec un système d'affixe bien rôdé (Diablo est certainement une influence), une feuille de statistique aux petits oignons qui vous fera longuement hésiter entre le couteau de cuisine et le rouleau à patisserie, ce dernier étant probablement plus efficace contre les squelettes. La traditionnelle montée de niveau au fil de l'expérience glanée est bien entendu au rendez-vous.
Tout ceci jusqu'à ce que mort s'ensuive. Et mort s'ensuit... Assez vite probablement. Et la mort, contrairement à ce que d'autres jeux vous font croire, c'est définitif. Totalement. Ne restent que vos souvenirs, vos larmes, et surtout les bonnes leçons apprises par le joueur. Qui en redemande ! Car la difficulté ne rebute pas, elle pousse à creuser plus avant. La rejouabilité et le plaisir aux dépens de la frustration dès les premières parties augurent du bon équilibrage du titre.

Bénéficiant des 150 ans d'expérience au service du développement de jeux vidéo au sein de la pépinière Canard PC, Verlies 2 remporte haut la main le label rouge bio de la madeleine de Proust.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984626177', 'num_games_owned': 1200, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1443288929}
review:
Quel plaisir de voir ce jeu en version release sur steam !
Pour moins de 10 euros, vous avez un Dungeon Crawler au design inspiré comics qui n'a aucune pitié pour le joueur, et pour cause : la génération du donjon qu'il faut traverser est géré de manière entièrement aléatoire. Et il en va de même pour les monstres ou l'équipement, avec un système d'affixes qui rend le loot forcément attractif puisqu'on récupère là un des éléments importants des hack'n slash.

J'aime beaucoup les dessins des personnages importants qu'on va voir en ville. Le fonctionnement du jeu rappelle vraiment les bons Dungeon Crawlers d'autrefois, avec deux sessions de jeu bien séparées : le passage en ville avec les traditionnels Temple / Forgeron / Auberge / Alchimiste etc, et puis le donjon proprement dit, qu'il faut essayer de traverser jusqu'au tout dernier étage.
On appréciera au passage la musique, très agréable, ainsi que le fait de débloquer pas mal de personnages au fil du jeu, ce qui renouvelle le plaisir des parties (de toutes façons, le côté full-random assure une très bonne rejouabilité).

L'évolution du personnage me plait dans le sens où il n'y a pas de classes de personnages. Les skills sont répartis en trois catégories : Arts de la Guerre / Arts des Arcanes / Arts de la Chasse, et chaque catégorie contient bon nombre de compétences actives et passives. De quoi se bricoler son perso aux petits oignons, comme on le désire.

Ceux qui aiment les challenges vont se régaler car le jeu est corsé, très corsé même et il va falloir s'accrocher pour voir le bout du donjon ! Si jamais vous faites partie des hommes de goût qui ont autrefois écumé les Wizardry ou les antiques Might and Magic, ce jeu risque de vous faire beaucoup de bien !
C'est un coup de coeur, assurément^^.

review:
DISCLAIMER: First impressions based on 30 mins of playtime.
Check out my First Impressions video here for gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jgy-xJpbixY

This is actually a pretty hard rogue-like dungeon crawler with unlockable characters and lots of items to find. I like the art style a lot.  

The translation of the dialogue and texts have funny little mistakes like "Donjon" for "Dungeon" etc. The game comes off as rather crude (developed by 1 guy)  but if you can look past that and enjoy the rogue-like and dungeon crawling genre this may very well be for you. 

You'll primarily be managing your resources (potions etc), skills and items trying to complete the dungeons and beat the bosses.
